Cell.Data: FSB582-C++ Standards Model Summary for C++
The LDRA tool suite® is developed and certified to BS EN ISO 9001:2000.
This information is applicable to version 9.4.4 of the LDRA tool suite®. It is correct as of 25th April 2014.

Compliance is measured against "C++ Coding Standard: Flight Software Branch - Code 582 Version 1.0" 2003 Copyright © NASA
Further information is available at http://aetd.gsfc.nasa.gov/code580

Header.x:Data: &CVersion 9.4.4 Copyright © 2014 LDRA Ltd. Copies of this document are not to be made or distributed.

Cell.Data: FSB582-C++ Standards Model Compliance for C++
Compiler options shall be selected such that non-conformances to the ISO/IEC 14882 standard are elevated to errors.
Array initialisation has too many items.
Array with no bounds in struct.
A given software unit shall only reference data applicable to its unit. If a unit references data from multiple units, then a redesign may be in order.
Explicit constants, (i.e., "hard coded" numbers) should not be used, except to establish identifiers to represent them (0 and 1 may be exceptions).
Use of numeric literal in expression.
Use of preprocessor directives or macros should be minimized in C++.
Only one object should be declared per declaration.
More than one variable per declaration.
Variables shall not be declared within loops.
asserts shall not be included in delivered code
Auto-generated code should not be modified.
Types should be typedef'd instead of relying on the default action of the compiler.
Typedef name has no size indication.
A const shall never be converted to a non-const.
Type casting should not be used
static declarations inside methods should be used sparingly.
Function has persistent local side effects.
Function has static member variable side effects.
Void function has static member variable side effects.
The C++ constructs true and false shall be used for Boolean values
throw/catch shall not be used in Interrupt Service Routines (ISRs).
Objects should be dynamically allocated only once at initialization, immediately following boot-up.
Memory shall be de-allocated in the same scope in which it was allocated.
malloc and free shall not be used
Use of banned function or variable.
Variables or objects created with new shall be deleted with delete.
Array delete shall be used for array objects.
A pointer shall never be used after it has been deleted.
File extensions should be *.cpp and *.h or *.hpp.
Base filename should indicate what class is defined therein.
Header file name does not include class name.
File name does not contain defined class name.
Each file should define or implement one class.
More than one class in header file.
The grouping of methods, within each section (public, private, protected), should be consistent throughout all classes for a project.
File length, including white space and comments, should not exceed 1000 lines.
Header files shall be protected with an #ifndef read-once latch.
Each header file shall #include the files it needs to compile. #includes shall be limited to what the header needs.
Header files shall not generate object code.
Quotes should be used to include files in the project source tree.
A class should be declared with a maximum of one of each of the following sections, in the order public, protected, private.
Certain methods of a class should be implemented.
No copy constructor for class with pointers.
No assignment operator for class with pointers.
No destructor for class with pointers.
No default constructor declared for class.
Virtual class members need virtual destructor.
No copy constructor for complex destructor.
No assignment operator for complex destrtor.
No copy ctor for templated copy ctor.
No assgnmt optor for templated assgmnt op.
Public data members shall never be used; all data members should be private.
Class data is not explicitly private.
friend classes shall never be used.
Multiple inheritance shall never be used.
The use of global variables and functions should be avoided.
Global variable should be declared const.
Classes should be used instead of structures.
A class's declaration should make clear the logical usage of the class.
Upon creation, an object created from a class shall be in a valid state, ready to be used.
User-defined types shall be passed by reference.
Code shall never return a reference or pointer to a local variable.
Local pointer returned in function result.
Local structure returned in function result.
Inline functions shall only be used for access methods and limited to three (3) lines or less.
Inline member has more than *** source lines.
Inline methods definitions shall be placed in the implementation (body) file.
The return type of a method shall be provided explicitly.
Methods that accept no parameters should have an explicit parameter list of void.
Class methods should use const wherever possible.
Member function may be declared const.
The virtual keyword shall be used to identify a modified inherited method.
The formal arguments of methods shall have names, and the same names should be used in both the method declaration and the method definition.
Procedure parameter has a type but no identifier.
When declaring methods, the leading parenthesis and the first argument (if any) should be written on the same line as the method name.
First parameter not on same line as function.
Method length, including white space and comments, should not exceed 100 lines.
Procedure exceeds *** source lines of code.
Constructors should initialize each data member in the class to a valid default value.
Members should appear in an initialization list in the order in which they are declared, one per line and equally indented.
Constructors and Destructors shall never be inline.
delete should be called on all pointer members in a destructor.
Objects created with new should, when possible, be delete'd in the reverse order.
Overloaded Operators shall not change the meaning of C++ operators.
When an operator has an opposite both shall be defined.
If the operator "=" is overloaded, it shall return a reference to *this.
If the operator "="is overloaded, all data members shall be assigned.
If the operator "="is overloaded, it shall include an assignment to self.

The flow control primitives if, else, while, for, and do should be followed by a block. If an empty block is used, a comment indicating that the block is intentionally left blank should be used to indicate that the code is complete.
No brackets to loop body (added by Testbed).
No brackets to then/else (added by Testbed).
The switch statement should be used instead of long if---else if--- chains whenever tests for equality of scalar expressions are being made.
The use of the loop constructs do, while, and for shall follow the recommendations of Kernighan and Ritchie .
More than one control variable for loop.
Modification of loop counter in loop body.
Non boolean control variable modified in loop.
Attempt to open file pointer more than once.
For loop incrementation is not simple.
Loop counter increment and operator defect.
Extra loop control variable is not bool.
Nesting levels greater than six (6) deep should not be used.
The ternary conditional operator ( ?: ) shall not be nested.
Only one exit point ( return ) should be used in a single method.
Procedure has more than one exit point.
The code following a case label shall be terminated by a break statement.
Switch case not terminated with break.
A switch statement shall always contain a default case.
No default case in switch statement.
breaks shall only be used in switch statements
Use of break statement in loop.
unsigned shall be used only for variables that cannot have negative values.
Inclusive lower limits and exclusive upper limits shall be used.
The continue statement shall never be used.
Logical operators shall not be used on non-Boolean values.
Parentheses shall be used to clarify the order of evaluation for operators in expressions.
Parentheses shall be used on the operand of << and >> IO operators.
Side effects within expressions should be used sparingly.
Function has global variable side effects.
Potential side effect problem in expression.
Potential side effect from repeated function call.
Call has execution order dependant side effects.
Deprecated usage of ++ or -- operators found.
The layout style of an if---else if-- chain should be as specified.
{ or } not on line by itself.
An if---else if--- chain shall always end with an else clause.
Empty else clause following else if.
|| and && should not be used with right-hand operands having side effects.
Call has execution order dependant side effects.
Use of ++ or -- on RHS of && or || operator.
Volatile variable accessed on RHS of && or ||.
Whenever || and && are mixed in the same expression, parentheses should be used for clarity.
Styles for brackets and indenting shall be consistent throughout the project.
{ or } not on line by itself.
The format of a switch statement should be as specified.
No default case in switch statement.
Default is not last case of switch.
Braces delineating blocks shall be in one of the specified forms.
{ or } not on line by itself.
All code should be indented a minimum of three spaces for each indentation level
Statements at the same logical nesting level should be at the same level of indentation.
Tabular indentation shall not be used
Each line should contain only one statement.
Declaration statement not on new line.
Statement not on new line (added by Testbed).
Blank lines should be used between blocks of code that are functionally.
A minimum of two blank lines should separate individual functions.
Less than *** blank lines separating procs.
A minimum of one blank line should separate the declarations and the code in a method.
Blank spaces should be used anywhere where spacing improves readability.
No space between if, while, for and expresn.
No space after semi colon in for expression.
Space missing before or after binary operator.
No space after comma in parameter list.
Spaces should not be used around '.' or '->' , or between unary operators and operands
Space between unary operator and operand.
* or & not attached to name in declaration.
Source lines shall not exceed 120 characters in length.
Groups of data assignments should be aligned.
All code shall be appropriately commented.
A block comment with the appropriate configuration management tags should be included at the top of all files.
Code that has been "commented out" shall be removed.
All class header files shall contain a prolog.
Full English sentences or intelligible phrases shall be used for comments.
The purpose of code blocks should be explained with separate comments indented at the same level as the code.
Comments should be included as "paragraph headers" to a block of code rather than to comment every line.
A comment should follow the declaration of a variable whenever it clarifies its usage.
Statement and variable comments should line up.
Each global variable shall have a comment explaining its usage.
Anything obvious should not be commented.
No comment should be followed by program code on the same line.
A space shall be inserted between the text of a comment and the delimiters //, /*, and */.
Variable names should never begin with an underscore.
Class names must identify the type of object they represent.
Global Variable does not conform to style g_<name>.
Class Member does not conform to style m_<name>.
Class Name does not conform to style C<name>.
Enum Name does not conform to style E<name>.
